text: We’re negotiating a 5-year sponsorship package with ESPN properties and Disney is the parent. response_text:
Below are two draft contract clauses you can use or adapt. The first is a concise version you can drop into a sponsorship agreement. The second is a more detailed version (with notice, cure/negotiation periods, valuation option, and remedies) that gives Sponsor both a re-pricing mechanism and a clear exit if parties cannot agree. Version A — Concise change‑of‑control / spin‑off clause
1. Definitions. For purposes of this Section, “Change of Control” means: (a) any sale, transfer or disposition (whether by merger, consolidation, sale of equity, sale of substantially all assets or otherwise) of ESPN or any material part of ESPN’s business to a third party; (b) any spin‑off, distribution or separation of ESPN from The Walt Disney Company (or any parent or affiliate) that results in ESPN becoming a separately controlled entity; or (c) any other transaction or series of transactions that results in a third party acquiring the ability to control the management or policies of ESPN (whether by ownership, contract or otherwise).

2. Notice. ESPN shall provide Sponsor written notice at least thirty (30) days prior to any proposed Change of Control (or, if shorter notice is legally required, promptly upon becoming legally permitted to provide notice), describing the proposed transaction in reasonable detail.

3. Sponsor Rights Upon Change of Control. If a Change of Control occurs during the Term:
   a. Re‑pricing. Sponsor may, within thirty (30) days after Sponsor’s receipt of notice of the Change of Control, deliver written notice requesting renegotiation of Sponsorship Fees and/or material commercial terms. The parties shall negotiate in good faith for a period of thirty (30) days. If the parties do not reach agreement within that period, Sponsor may terminate this Agreement as set forth below.
   b. Termination. If Sponsor elects not to renegotiate or if renegotiation does not result in agreement, Sponsor may terminate this Agreement by written notice to ESPN, effective thirty (30) days after delivery of such termination notice. Upon termination Sponsor shall receive a refund of any prepaid Fees attributable to the unrendered portion of the Term and neither party shall have further liability for obligations accruing after the effective date of termination, except for obligations expressly stated to survive.

4. Successors. Any acquirer, successor or assignee of ESPN (including a resulting spin‑off entity) shall assume and be bound by ESPN’s obligations hereunder.

Version B — Detailed change‑of‑control / spin‑off clause with valuation option
1. Definitions. “Change of Control” means (i) a sale or transfer of ownership or voting control of ESPN or of a majority of the equity or voting interests of the entity that owns ESPN; (ii) a sale or transfer of substantially all of ESPN’s assets; (iii) a spin‑off or separation of ESPN from The Walt Disney Company such that ESPN becomes a separately controlled, publicly traded or privately held entity; or (iv) any other transaction or series of transactions that results in a third party acquiring the ability to direct ESPN’s management or policies.

2. Advance Notice. ESPN shall provide Sponsor written notice of any proposed Change of Control promptly upon public announcement of the transaction and, in any event, no later than thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of such Change of Control (or as soon as legally permissible).

3. Sponsor Options Following Change of Control. If a Change of Control occurs during the Term, Sponsor shall have the following rights:
   a. Good‑Faith Renegotiation. Within thirty (30) days after Sponsor’s receipt of the notice required by Section 2, Sponsor may elect in writing to renegotiate Sponsorship Fees and/or any material commercial terms. Upon such election the parties shall meet and negotiate in good faith for a period of up to forty‑five (45) days to agree revised terms that reflect the commercial impact of the Change of Control.
   b. Independent Valuation (optional). If Sponsor elects renegotiation and the parties are unable to agree on revised Fees within the negotiation period, Sponsor may elect to have the change in commercial value determined by an independent media valuation expert mutually agreed by the parties (or, if the parties cannot agree on one expert within ten (10) business days, each party shall select one expert and the two experts shall select a third; the determination of the third expert shall be final and binding). The expert shall determine the fair market value of the sponsorship rights under this Agreement post‑Change of Control compared to pre‑Change of Control, and shall recommend an adjustment to Fees (if any). The expert’s fees shall be borne equally, provided that if the expert’s recommendation results in a Sponsor‑favorable price reduction of more than ten percent (10%), ESPN shall bear 100% of the expert fees.
   c. Termination Right. If (i) Sponsor elects not to renegotiate, (ii) renegotiation does not produce an agreement within the negotiation period, or (iii) Sponsor rejects the independent valuation recommendation, Sponsor may terminate this Agreement by written notice to ESPN, effective thirty (30) days after delivery of such notice.

4. Remedies on Termination. Upon termination pursuant to Section 3(c):
   a. Refund. ESPN shall promptly refund to Sponsor any prepaid Fees prorated to the effective date of termination for Sponsorship benefits not yet delivered.
   b. Wind‑Down. The parties shall cooperate on a commercially reasonable wind‑down of obligations and use commercially reasonable efforts to minimize disruption to either party. Termination shall not relieve either party of liabilities accrued prior to the effective date of termination.

5. Assumption by Successor. Any purchaser, successor or assignee of ESPN shall, as a condition of the Change of Control, assume all obligations under this Agreement in writing or Sponsor may exercise its rights under Section 3.

6. Survival. The rights set forth in this Section shall survive any Change of Control and shall be the exclusive remedy of Sponsor with respect to any Change of Control (except for claims of fraud or willful breach).

- How long a negotiation/cure period is reasonable (commonly 30–90 days).
- Whether you want an independent valuation procedure vs. a simple termination right.
- Whether to include a termination fee (to cover sunk activation costs) rather than or in addition to a pro rata refund.
- Whether you want to limit triggers to material changes that materially affect the value of the sponsorship (i.e., a Material Adverse Effect test) rather than any transfer.
- Whether the successor must step into ESPN’s shoes by written assumption.

text: I run a sports bar and was considering branding a big renovation around “ESPN” and Disney tie-ins for the next few years. Is there enough risk of ESPN changing hands before 2028 that I should keep the branding more generic?

response_text:
Short answer: It’s unlikely — but not impossible — that ESPN will change ownership before 2028. The bigger, more immediate risk for your renovation is legal exposure from using ESPN/Disney trademarks without permission and the practical hassle of tying your brand to an outside company you don’t control. I would avoid permanent, expensive rebranding built around ESPN/Disney unless you secure a formal licensing or co‑branding agreement.

Why:
- Ownership risk: ESPN is a major cash‑generating asset. A sale or spin‑off would be a high‑profile, complex transaction that likely takes years and board/regulatory approval. That makes a forced change before 2028 relatively unlikely but not impossible given how fast the media landscape can shift.
- Trademark/licensing risk: Regardless of ownership, ESPN and Disney aggressively protect their IP. Using their logos, trade dress, or Disney characters in your signage, menus, or marketing without a license risks cease‑and‑desist letters, fines, or forced removal. Even saying “We show ESPN” is different from using the ESPN logo as part of your official business name or décor.
- Practical risk: If an ownership change happens, the new owner might change branding, licensing terms, or enforcement posture — which could force you to remove or change branded elements later.

Recommended approach:
1. Don’t do permanent, expensive branding (channeled neon, custom exterior signage, etched glass, major murals) using ESPN/Disney marks unless you have a licensing agreement.
2. Use modular, replaceable décor: removable banners, digital graphics on LEDs/TVs, temporary posters, or themed furniture you can resell or repaint.
3. Promote that you “carry ESPN” only if you legitimately have the channel (and avoid using their logo as your primary business mark). For on‑site signs, nominative fair use is narrow — get advice before using the ESPN wordmark or logo.
4. Consider a generic house identity that evokes a sports‑network vibe without copying ESPN (color palette, phrases like “The Fourth Quarter,” “Playbook Bar,” “Sideline Sportsbar”), so a rebrand would be unnecessary if corporate logos must be removed.
5. If you want formal ESPN branding, contact Disney/ESPN licensing to discuss commercial-use permissions and costs — but expect high fees and strict requirements.
6. Budget a contingency (design/signage cost) in case you need to change branded elements later, and consult an IP attorney beforehand to review proposed designs.

Bottom line: The chance of ESPN changing hands by 2028 is not high enough to be the main reason to avoid ESPN-themed branding. The real reason to be cautious is trademark/licensing risk and loss of control. Keep your core branding generic and use removable ESPN/Disney elements only with permission (or as temporary décor) so you protect your investment and avoid legal trouble.

text: I'm analyzing potential M&A targets in sports media. Saw a Bloomberg piece suggesting Disney might separate ESPN in the next few years. My boss thinks it's worth exploring acquisition scenarios, but I'm not sure if this is serious enough to dedicate resources to. What's your read?
proposition: Disney will sell or spin off ESPN as a separate company before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Short answer
- Bloomberg’s report is plausible but not a slam-dunk. There are good strategic reasons Disney could separate ESPN in the next 1–3 years, but there are also strong countervailing reasons to hold it. Probability: moderate.
- Recommendation: do a light, focused “go/no‑go” feasibility study now (2–4 weeks, small team) to decide whether to commit full M&A resources. If that produces a positive view on value/fit, move to a full acquisition readiness/diligence plan.

Why the Bloomberg rumor is plausible
- Cash and focus: Disney has been reorienting toward streaming and simplifying its portfolio. Spin-offs/carpets help unlock shareholder value and simplify reporting.
- Value realization: Some investors and analysts believe ESPN’s cash flows are undervalued inside Disney’s broader valuation—separation can surface that value.
- Rights-cost pressure: Rising rights fees and cord-cutting make ESPN’s future economics more uncertain; Disney may want to ring-fence the asset.
- Precedents: Large media companies have been restructuring and divesting non-core linear assets recently.

Why Disney might not sell/spin ESPN
- Strategic bundle: ESPN is a cornerstone of Disney’s pay-TV bundle—it helps negotiate carriage deals and bundles with Disney’s streaming services.
- High, sticky cash flows: Linear affiliate fees and live-sports ad demand still generate large, relatively stable cash flows.
- Complexity and stigma: A carve-out is messy—long-term rights, league contracts, distribution agreements, and cross-company customer flows complicate separation.
- Execution risk: Disney may prefer other options (carve-out with retained stake, joint venture, IPO, or licensing) over a full sale.

Key factors that will determine whether a separation/sale actually happens
- Financial performance trends: affiliate fees, ad revenue trends, ESPN+ ARPU, churn, and subscriber economics.
- Long-term rights commitments: length and size of NFL/MLB/NBA/college rights commitments and escalation clauses.
- Disney corporate strategy and capital allocation priorities (streaming investment vs returning capital).
- Investor/board/activist pressure and market valuation dynamics.
- Availability of credible bidders and the prices they’re willing to pay.

Who would realistically buy (or partner)
- Private equity consortiums (often with partners for operating expertise).
- Tech/platform companies seeking live sports distribution (Amazon, Apple, Netflix-type bidders), though antitrust and price could be barriers.
- Cable/MSO or broadcaster consolidators (Comcast, Paramount-type), though regulatory issues and scale matter.
- Sports gambling companies or consortiums combining betting with content (partial stakes or JV).
- Strategic consortiums: PE + sports rights/journalism operators + distribution partners.

High-level deal and integration considerations for a buyer
- Structure: full buyout, majority stake, minority carve-out with long-term distribution commitments, JV, or taking a controlling piece of a spun-out public company.
- Rights and contracts: detailed review of national and local broadcast rights, exclusivity, sublicensing, reconciliation clauses, renewal windows and breakpoints.
- Distribution: carriage agreements, MVPD/virtual MVPD economics, digital distribution (ESPN+, Hulu Live), retransmission consent mechanics.
- Cost base: rights amortization, production costs, linear channel operating costs, technology and app infrastructure.
- Synergies: subscriber cross-sell, advertising stack modernization, sports-betting integration, distribution cost reductions.
- Financing: likely large equity + debt; sports assets can carry high leverage but are sensitive to rights-driven cost shocks.
- People/operations: editorial independence, union contracts, production talent retention.

Regulatory and league/competition issues
- Antitrust review likely if a major strategic buyer (inspectorate for market consolidation).
- League consent and rules: leagues sometimes restrict who can hold broadcast rights or co-ownership conflicts with team owners.
- Foreign owner restrictions depending on buyer nationality.
- Media ownership rules and retrans/regulatory frameworks.

Valuation approach (how to think about price)
- Use multiple scenarios: base, downside (continued cord-cutting), upside (successful streaming monetization + betting).
- Primary methods: DCF with scenario testing; precedent M&A multiples for sports networks; sum-of-the-parts if carve-out includes multiple assets (linear networks, streaming subs, digital/data).
- Key inputs: affiliate fees per sub, ad CPMs, ESPN+ ARPU & churn, rights cost trajectory, capex and tech spend.
- Result will be sensitive to the discount rate,rights-cost inflation assumptions, and growth of direct-to-consumer revenue.

Practical next steps (recommended immediate actions)
1. Run a 2–4 week feasibility study (small cross-functional team)
   - Team: 1–2 senior M&A/strategy leads, 1 media/sports specialist, 1 financial analyst, counsel/advisory on rights law as needed.

2. Data to assemble for the study (if public data is insufficient)
   - Historical P&L for ESPN (revenue by stream: affiliate fees, ads, DTC, other; costs broken down).
   - ESPN+ subscriber & engagement metrics, ARPU, churn.
   - Schedule of major rights contracts and renewal dates + escalators.
   - Carriage & retransmission agreements and bundle exposure.
   - Capital and operating cost items for the networks and streaming platforms.

3. If feasibility is positive: plan a structured approach to move forward
   - Prepare an acquisition model; prepare financing plan and potential consortium partners.
   - Start discreet outreach to possible partners/buyers to test appetite and price.
   - Prep for IP/confidentiality/data-room readiness in case a process opens quickly.

Go/no-go criteria to use at end of the light study
- Can we build a credible 3–5 year plan that produces acceptable IRR at plausible financing/leverage?
- Are there credible buyers/partners to limit price and execution risk?
- Are there legal/contractual blockers (e.g., unavoidable runaway rights costs or league consent problems)?
- Does the asset offer strategic synergies that materially improve value vs buying later?

Bottom line
- This is a credible rumor and could become an actionable opportunity. But the asset is complex and potentially expensive, with many contractual and strategic landmines.
- You should not commit a full M&A team yet, but you should fund a short, focused feasibility study now so you’re positioned to move quickly if Disney actually signals a separation or sale.

proposition: Disney will sell or spin off ESPN as a separate company before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Good question — the possibility of a spin‑off changes what risks you’re taking and therefore what you should ask and try to lock into an offer. Below I give (A) neutral, interview‑friendly questions to surface ESPN/Disney plans and employee protections, (B) the specific comp/contract terms to push for if a spin‑off is possible, and (C) negotiation strategy and role selection tips so you can weigh upside vs. downside.

A. Questions to ask (during interview / with hiring manager / with HR)
Keep the tone curious and pragmatic — you don’t need to sound alarmist.

Operational & strategic questions (ask hiring manager / leadership)
- How do you see ESPN’s strategy and capital allocation evolving over the next 12–36 months?  
- Has leadership discussed potential corporate separation or changes in ownership formally? If so, what’s the anticipated timeline or decision process?  
- If a separation happens, what parts of the organization are expected to be core vs. at risk? (teams, contracts, shared services)  
- How would budgets, hiring, and headcount be managed in the near term if a separation is being explored?

Equity / liquidity questions (ask HR / compensation)
- What equity instruments does ESPN offer (RSUs, options, phantom equity)? Who is the actual equity issuer today (Disney) and how would that change in a spin‑off?  
- If ESPN were to be spun off, what is the expected treatment of outstanding equity awards (conversion, acceleration, liquidity, tax consequences)?  
- Historically, how has Disney treated equity on divestitures? Is there precedent you can point me to?

Change‑in‑control / severance questions (ask HR)
- Does the company have a standard severance policy for my level? Can you describe typical severance (months of base, bonus treatment, COBRA, outplacement)?  
- Are there plans for retention bonuses or change‑in‑control protections if a separation occurs?  
- How is “termination without cause” and “good reason” defined in severance/change‑in‑control provisions?

Role & career questions (ask hiring manager)
- If a change in ownership occurs, what will my team’s reporting and responsibilities likely look like? How portable are the skills/relationships I’d build here?  
- Would the role be expected to participate in separation planning/transition work? If so, would that be compensated/recognized separately?

Practical / employee experience questions (ask peers / recruiter)
- Have there been recent restructurings/layoffs? What was the process and severance experience like?

B. What to push for in comp/offer language (practical priorities)
How you prioritize depends on your risk tolerance: if you want upside, accept more equity but push for protections; if you want security, push cash and severance.

1) Base salary
- Get market‑competitive base pay. If you’re worried about instability, favor more base (cash) vs. equity.

2) Signing bonus & guaranteed first‑year compensation
- Ask for a sign‑on bonus and/or guaranteed minimum bonus for year one (e.g., sign‑on to offset lost bonus from previous employer; a guaranteed pro‑rated bonus if company bonus is uncertain).

3) Annual bonus / target
- Get target bonus % documented and ask whether it is discretionary or formulaic. If possible, negotiate that any sign‑on or guaranteed bonus be paid even if the company is in transition.

4) Equity — clarify type and treatment
- Ask that the offer specify the equity vehicle (RSUs, options, phantom).  
- Seek accelerated vesting on a Change‑in‑Control (CIC) event and/or on involuntary termination following CIC. Typical language candidates request:
  - Double‑trigger: full vesting of unvested awards if terminated without cause or for good reason within X months after a CIC. (Common/acceptable.)
  - Single‑trigger: immediate vesting on CIC (companies resist this more). If company won’t do single‑trigger, push for double‑trigger plus strong severance.

5) Severance / change‑in‑control protections
- Negotiate a written severance clause: for mid‑level finance roles, target 3–12 months base salary (depending on level) + pro‑rated bonus; for senior finance, 12–24 months. Include:
  - Pay period (lump sum or continuation), bonus treatment (pro‑rata or guaranteed), COBRA continuation or equivalent health coverage.  
  - Define “termination without cause” and “good reason” precisely.  
- If a spin‑off is likely, ask for a retention/transaction bonus payable on completion of the spin‑off or on a set date if the transaction occurs.

6) Acceleration / liquidity specifics
- Require clarity about conversion of Disney equity to new company equity and whether there will be lock‑ups or public listing timelines. If possible, negotiate partial cash protection if awards convert to illiquid equity.

7) Other protections/perks to negotiate
- Outplacement assistance, extended health benefits, accrued bonus guarantee, relocation reimbursement, flexible work or remote options.
- Title and responsibilities documented in the offer so role is not downgraded post‑transaction.

C. Sample contract language (phrases you can request)
- “If Employee’s employment is terminated by the Company without Cause, or Employee terminates for Good Reason, within 12 months following a Change in Control, Employee will receive [12 months’ base salary] and a pro‑rated target bonus for the year of termination, and 100% acceleration of unvested equity awards.”  
- “If the Company is spun off and equity awards are converted into non‑public equity, the Company agrees to provide a cash retention bonus equal to [X% of base] payable on consummation, and will provide liquidity guidance within [90] days.”

D. Role selection & career strategy
- Prefer roles that are (a) core to the business (revenue/FP&A, investor relations, M&A, treasury) or (b) highly portable (modeling, commercial finance, deal experience). These are more likely to be retained and valuable to a buyer or new public company.  
- Avoid hyper‑specialized roles tightly coupled to Disney systems/processes unless compensated accordingly.

E. Negotiation timing & tactics
- Don’t ask for all contract protections in the first screening — surface strategic questions early and save legal/compensation specifics for HR/offer stage.  
- Use market comps to justify higher base/bonus/ severance. Get the offer in writing and involve a lawyer for severance/change‑in‑control language if needed.  
- If you want upside but worry about downside: accept some equity but ask for stronger severance + retention bonus + double‑trigger acceleration.

F. Practical checklist before accepting
- Confirm the equity vehicle, expected treatment in a spin‑off, and any planned retention payments.  
- Get severance/change‑in‑control protections in writing (or at least clarity on company policy).  
- Decide your personal risk preference (more cash & protections vs. more equity upside) and make that your negotiation theme.

If you’d like, tell me: your role level (associate, manager, director), target comp band, and how risk‑averse you are, and I’ll suggest concrete severance/months and sample language tailored to your level.

text: We’re about to sign a 3-year ad-buy with ESPN and my boss thinks Disney is likely to spin ESPN off before 2028. He wants me to negotiate hard on make-goods and continuity if the sales team changes post-spin. What specific terms should I insist on, assuming a separation is fairly likely?
proposition: Disney will sell or spin off ESPN as a separate company before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Good plan to prepare for a likely separation. Below I list concrete contract terms, clauses and negotiation tactics you should insist on if a Disney/ESPN spin seems probable. I group them by priority (must-haves first), then give sample language snippets you can adapt with legal counsel.

Top priorities (must include)
1. Change‑of‑control / assignment protection
   - Define “change of control” explicitly (spin‑off, de‑merger, sale of >X% of equity, IPO with majority ownership change, etc.).
   - Requirement: any spin/assignment requires the successor to (a) assume all advertiser obligations, (b) provide a parent guarantee until assumption occurs, or (c) allow advertiser to terminate with full refund + break fee.
   - Require written notice of any pending change of control at least 60–90 days before closing.

2. Successor liability + parent guarantee
   - If the spun entity or buyer does not expressly assume the contract and provide equivalent performance, require Disney (parent) to remain liable (guarantee) until contract completion or until successor acceptance.
   - If parent insists on assignment without guarantee, require advertiser consent (not to be unreasonably withheld).

3. Escrow / retention of prepayments
   - For significant prepayments, require either (a) funds held in escrow and released monthly as inventory is delivered, or (b) a holdback (e.g., 10–15%) payable only as campaign performance is confirmed, or (c) a parent guarantee covering prepaid amounts.
   - Alternatively, require automatic credit/refund mechanism if spin occurs and obligations aren’t assumed.

4. Make‑goods / remediation spelled out and strengthened for change of control
   - Define delivery guarantees precisely: GRPs/impressions/reach/dayparts/demos, and the measurement system (Nielsen, comScore, MRC‑certified viewability).
   - Make‑good hierarchy: top priority is additional equivalent inventory in same dayparts/demos; if not feasible within X days, advertiser gets cash refund at current market rates + premium.
   - For shortfalls attributable to the spin or post‑spin operational disruption, require improved remedy (e.g., make‑goods + 25% bonus or cash at 125–150% of shortfall value).
   - Time windows for make‑goods: require they occur within 30–90 days of detection and before credits expire.
   - Credits must be usable against equivalent or better premium inventory (not just remnant inventory) and must not be subject to arbitrary blackout periods.

5. Right to terminate for material adverse change (MAC)
   - If spin or post‑spin operations materially reduce campaign value (inventory, data, measurement changes, inability to traffic or bill fairly), you get (a) pro‑rata refund of undelivered portion, and (b) an optional break fee (negotiable, e.g., 10–25% of remaining spend) to cover switching costs.
   - Define “material adverse change” with examples: loss of access to live sports inventory, change in measurement methodology that reduces reported delivery materially, inability to deliver agreed demos/dayparts.

6. Measurement, reporting, and audit rights
   - Require access to raw delivery logs, third‑party verification (Nielsen/comScore/IAB‑compliant), viewability and IVT reporting.
   - Strong audit rights: right to audit ad logs and reconciliation, with vendor obligation to preserve data for ≥24 months.
   - If the spin creates a new measurement methodology, require prior written agreement on equivalency testing and no unilateral change for at least 12–24 months post‑closing.

7. Transition Services Agreement (TSA) commitments
   - Require that any spin includes a TSA obligating the old/new entity to provide trafficking, billing, reporting, data access and customer service for at least 12–24 months (negotiable) on identical terms.
   - Require SLA metrics for time to load creatives, reporting cadence, billing cycle, and contact escalation path.

Secondary but important items
8. Sales/account continuity / key‑person protections
   - Name an account team and require notice + replacement plan if key personnel leave.
   - Service level guarantees: response times, meeting cadence, escalation matrix.
   - If sales coverage materially changes, provide additional make‑goods or price concessions.

9. Data portability and first‑party data access
   - Guarantee access to campaign analytics, audience segments, IDs and logs in machine‑readable form on termination or spin.
   - No lock‑in: require ability to port measurement and audience data to buyers’ DSP/partner.

10. No unilateral price or inventory allocation changes
    - Prohibit unilateral rate increases or changes to inventory allocation due to corporate restructuring.
    - If pricing materially changes post‑spin, allow termination or renegotiation.

11. Indemnities and insurance
    - Indemnify advertiser for misrepresentations about inventory, and require indemnity for any breach caused by the spin or successor’s actions.
    - Require professional liability and cyber insurance to cover data access failures.

12. Liquidated damages for failure to assume obligations
    - If successor refuses to assume or parent refuses guarantee, liquidated damages equal to a multiple (e.g., 125–150%) of the undelivered spend or lost value can be negotiated to deter non‑assumption.

13. Continuity of exclusivity / competitive protections
    - If exclusivity (category, competitor ads) was promised, require successor to enforce the same exclusivity during the ad period; if not feasible, provide stronger remediation.

14. Billing and credit terms continuity
    - Billing cadence, credit terms and invoices must remain unchanged; require transition provisions if finance processes change.

Practical negotiation mechanics and thresholds
- Insist on defined equivalency: “equivalent” means same demo, same daypart(s), same or better adj. CPM/GRP value, and same program inventory (e.g., live game vs. highlights).
- Tolerances: limit allowable shortfall per reporting period (e.g., ≤5%). Above tolerance triggers expanded remedies.
- Timing windows: require 30 days’ notice before credits expire; require make‑goods within 60–90 days.
- Escalate early: require a pre‑closing meeting on the transition plan and inventory mapping; require a signed transition schedule as a condition to closing.
- Use the leverage: demand these protections in exchange for your 3‑year commitment — spin risk is a material negotiation point.

Sample clauses (short forms — have counsel tailor)
1) Change‑of‑Control / Successor Liability
“If any Change of Control occurs during the Term, Seller shall (a) provide Purchaser with written notice no fewer than 60 days prior to closing; (b) require the successor to execute an assumption agreement expressly assuming all obligations under this Agreement; and (c) until such assumption agreement is executed, Disney [or Seller] shall remain liable for all obligations hereunder. If no assumption agreement is executed by closing, Purchaser may (i) terminate this Agreement with immediate effect and receive a full pro rata refund of prepaid amounts plus a termination fee equal to [X%] of the remaining committed spend, or (ii) elect continued performance under the remedies set out in Section [Make‑Goods].”

2) Make‑Goods for Change‑Related Shortfalls
“Deliverables are guaranteed as to [GRPs/impressions/reach] measured by [measurement vendor]. For any confirmed shortfall in excess of 5% for a given month, Seller shall provide Make‑Goods equal to the shortfall in equivalent inventory in the same dayparts/demos within 45 days. If Seller cannot provide equivalent premium inventory within 45 days, Seller shall remit cash equal to 125% of the fair market value of the shortfall, calculated per the methodology in Exhibit X.”

3) Escrow / Holdback
“Advertiser’s prepayments in excess of [30 days’ run‑rate] shall be held in a third‑party escrow account and released monthly upon Seller’s confirmation of delivered inventory. In the event of Change of Control where obligations are not assumed, escrowed funds shall be returned immediately to Advertiser.”

4) TSA Requirement
“Any Transferor and Transferee shall be required to enter into, and maintain for a minimum of 12 months post‑closing, a Transition Services Agreement providing for trafficking, reporting, billing, and customer support services at no additional cost to Advertiser and in substantially the same form and level of service as was provided pre‑closing.”

5) Audit & Data Portability
“Seller shall provide Advertiser with daily/weekly delivery logs, raw impression data and audience data in machine‑readable format, retain such data for 24 months, and permit Advertiser or its auditor to audit such data upon reasonable notice. Upon termination or Change of Control, Seller shall deliver all campaign data and audience segments to Advertiser within 10 business days.”

Negotiation priorities by what’s most likely to be contested
- Sales/operations teams: require TSAs and SLAs; this is usually doable.
- Parent guarantee/escrow: expect pushback — push harder if you prepay.
- Liquidated damages/premium refunds: will be heavily contested; if you can get a clear make‑goods + cash premium for spin‑related failure, take it.
- Restricting assignment: they’ll want flexibility; you want continuity — a compromise: allow assignment only with assumption + parent guarantee or buyer credit event.

Practical tips
- Involve legal and procurement early — these clauses are legal and finance heavy.
- Quantify your exposure (how much prepaid, revenue at risk) and use that to set acceptable holdback/escrow percentages.
- Ask for a pre‑closing transition plan with inventory mapping and a formal sign‑off right before any closing.
- If you can’t get full escrow or parent guarantee, secure the best make‑good/cash remedies and short credit expiration windows.
- Consider payment cadence changes (pay as you go) if spin timing aligns with large prepayments.

If you’d like, tell me:
- whether this is linear TV or digital inventory (or both),
- how much prepaid vs. invoiced spend there is,
- whether you need sample clause language tailored to TV (GRPs) or digital (impressions/viewability),
and I’ll draft more specific contract language you can hand off to counsel.

text: I’m thinking about buying Disney stock mainly because I heard they’ll probably sell/spin off ESPN in the next couple years and that could unlock value. I’m skeptical it’ll actually happen before 2028—should I treat that as a core part of the thesis or as a long-shot bonus?
proposition: Disney will sell or spin off ESPN as a separate company before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Short answer: treat an ESPN spin-off as a plausible upside catalyst but not as the core investment thesis unless you want to make a speculative bet. Put it in the “bonus” column for a buy decision today and size your position accordingly.

Why: probability, timing, and impact
- Probability: separation is plausible (ESPN is a distinct, cash-generating business with different economics from Disney’s studios/parks/streaming) but it’s also legally, operationally, and politically complex. My read: a material chance over many years, but a low-to-moderate chance of a completed, value-unlocking spin/sale by 2028 unless strong, visible catalyst/commitment appears.  
- Timing: spinoffs and sales at this scale typically take many quarters of planning (bankers, regulatory review, disentangling contracts and tech, tax planning). Expect 1–4+ years in normal circumstances; a 1–2 year timetable is optimistic.  
- Impact: if done well, a separation could re-rate ESPN on a higher multiple or realize value via sale; but the exact per-share uplift is uncertain and depends on price buyers are willing to pay or the standalone multiple.

A practical framework to decide how much weight to give it
1. Assign your own probability (p) that a spin/sale that meaningfully unlocks value completes by 2028. Be explicit. Example ranges people commonly use:
   - Conservative: p = 10–25%  
   - Moderate: p = 25–50%  
   - High conviction: p > 50%
2. Estimate the upside if it happens (U): realistic range, not headline numbers. If analysts/market talk about an unlocked value of X per share, use a range (low/median/high).  
3. Compute an expected contribution = p * U. Compare that to Disney’s current upside drivers from streaming recovery, parks, and content. If p * U is a small fraction of price, treat it as bonus; if material, you can treat as a meaningful part of the thesis.

Illustrative example (fill with your own numbers)
- Suppose you think separation could add $20/share (U) and you assign p = 30% → expected contribution = $6/share. If $6/share is small relative to your expected total return/valuation gap, it’s a bonus. If it’s large relative to the remaining upside you expect from other improvements, you might give it more weight.

Things that increase the odds
- Clear management statements/strategic review or hiring of advisors/bankers.  
- Activist investor involvement pushing for separation.  
- Market conditions that make buyers/lenders willing to take on ESPN’s rights-cost profile.  
- Contracts/rights cycle that favors a clean break.

Things that decrease the odds or slow the process
- Complex streaming-licensing and rights entanglements with cross-platform benefits.  
- Regulatory hurdles (antitrust, media ownership reviews in certain jurisdictions).  
- Management preference to keep control of sports content as a strategic asset for Disney+.  
- Market instability making buyers or high valuations scarce.

How to act with respect to your position
- Don’t make it the core thesis: base your primary buy/sell decision on Disney’s fundamentals (streaming trajectory, content, parks recovery, cost control). Treat ESPN separation as an optional upside.  
- If you want exposure to the catalyst but don’t want to overcommit, size it modestly—e.g., a small to medium position (2–6% of a diversified portfolio) unless you have high conviction and a strong view on timing/probability.  
- Alternatively, if available and liquid, use options to express a leveraged bet on a near-term catalyst while limiting downside.  
- Set clear re-evaluation triggers: management announces a strategic review, hires advisors, activist proxy filings, or a formal spin/sale announcement. Reassess allocation at those points.

Monitoring checklist (what to watch)
- Investor day commentary, 10-Q/10-K filings, or explicit management comments about ESPN strategy.  
- Hiring of banks/advisors or formation of a strategic review committee.  
- Activist investor filings or public pressure from large shareholders.  
- Major rights renewals/contract milestones that could change ESPN economics.  
- Market/industry M&A activity for comparable sports businesses.

Final recommendation
Unless you assign a high probability (>~40–50%) that ESPN is separated and value-unlocked by 2028, treat that outcome as a long-shot bonus rather than the foundation of a Disney investment. Base your core thesis on observable operational improvements and treat any ESPN scenario as upside. If you want exposure specifically to the spin-upside, size the portion of your holding that way and use the scenario/probability framework above to keep your expectations disciplined.

If you’d like, tell me (a) the probability you’d assign and (b) a plausible per‑share uplift number you’ve seen or think is reasonable, and I’ll calculate the expected contribution and suggest a position-sizing rule.

text: We’re planning a sports-media conference for 2027 and want ESPN leadership as keynotes and sponsors. If there’s a non-trivial chance ESPN is separated from Disney by then, how should we structure our invitations/sponsorship packages and backup options?
proposition: Disney will sell or spin off ESPN as a separate company before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Short answer
Plan for flexibility: invite ESPN leadership directly but design all sponsor offers, invitation language and contracts so they work whether ESPN is owned by Disney or by another parent in 2027. Build parallel outreach to Disney (if relevant) and maintain a ranked list of backup keynote/sponsor candidates you can convert quickly. Include specific contract protections (assignment/novation, change‑of‑control, replacement/termination and refund/credit mechanics), and ask legal counsel to draft precise trademark/branding and payment language.

Detailed, practical plan

1) Who to invite and how to phrase the invite
- Target people responsible for ESPN’s strategy and external partnerships (CEO/President of ESPN, Head of Content/Programming, Head of Ad Sales/Revenue, Chief Commercial Officer, Chief Marketing Officer). Also send a courtesy/outreach to the Disney executive who would oversee ESPN if it remains part of Disney.
- Use flexible, non‑assumptive language. Example invitation sentence:
  - “We would be honored to host [Name/Title] as a keynote speaker and to explore ESPN’s participation as a lead sponsor. For planning purposes, we welcome participation from ESPN (or the entity that operates the ESPN business as of the conference date), and will coordinate branding and legal approvals with the appropriate corporate owner at that time.”
- Ask for a soft hold or nonbinding LOI for keynote availability and/or sponsorship interest as early as possible (12–18 months ahead). Make clear there will be time to finalize logos, copy and approvals later.
- Ask for a named liaison in the org (corporate communications or partnerships) so approvals move smoothly whether they are inside Disney or a successor.

2) How to structure sponsorship packages
- Offer ESPN-branded benefits that don’t require Disney-level approvals up front (e.g., stage time, moderated fireside chat, onsite activation space, thought‑leadership sessions, digital content rights you control).
- Create two parallel options in the packet:
  - “ESPN as an independent sponsor” (contract with ESPN entity and use of ESPN branding);
  - “ESPN as part of parent company” (contract with parent company; broader cross‑brand activation if parent signs on).
- Make all benefits deliverable to the “ESPN brand” or “the operator of the ESPN business as of the event date” to avoid renaming or legal fuss if ownership changes.
- For title/lead sponsor tier: include guaranteed prime keynote slot plus co‑branding with conference title, on‑site media studio, a bespoke panel with ESPN leaders, and first right to renew next year.
- For all tiers: specify what’s included, deadlines for logo/asset delivery, approvals turnaround (e.g., 10 business days), and a PR coordination requirement.

3) Contract terms you should include (have legal draft)
- Assignment/novation clause: allow the sponsor to assign the agreement to a successor entity (or allow you to accept assignment) if ESPN is sold or spun out, with a notice requirement and opportunity to update contact/payment details.
- Change‑of‑control clause: permit you or the sponsor to renegotiate material terms if ESPN’s ownership changes; include the right to terminate for material adverse change with a defined refund/credit schedule.
- Performance/delivery specs: define exactly what constitutes delivery of sponsorship benefits (e.g., “30‑minute keynote by a C‑level ESPN executive” — if actual person changes, sponsor must provide equivalent seniority).
- Branding/usage: specify that you will use the ESPN name and logos only with the owner’s written consent, and include an automatic substitution mechanism that grants rights to the new owner/operator of the ESPN business in the event of a sale (but require trademark approvals within stated timelines).
- Payment and escrow: staged payments tied to milestones; consider holding a portion in escrow until final brand assets/approvals are provided. Define invoicing party and where to send payments if ownership changes.
- Termination & replacement: define refund/credit calculations and your right to replace a sponsor that withdraws because of ownership change with a comparable sponsor.
- Indemnity & insurance: standard indemnity and insurance requirements. Add a clause that lines up which entity will handle PR/legal fallout if a sale creates sensitive issues.
- Confidentiality & PR: require pre‑approval for any press release that links the sponsor to the event; require coordinated messaging around ownership changes.

4) Practical PR/branding and approvals workflow
- Ask sponsors to commit to an approvals contact and turnaround times (e.g., logo approval within 5 business days) so you don’t get stalled by corporate red tape.
- Prepare two brand kits in advance for key assets: one referencing “ESPN” and one referencing “ESPN (a [parent name]/independent)”. Keep legal counsel on standby for trademark clearance.
- If ESPN is still with Disney, expect longer lead times and more approvals — schedule earlier signoff deadlines for that scenario.

5) Backup sponsorship and keynote options (ranked examples)
- Other sports media/networks: Fox Sports, NBC Sports/Peacock (Paramount Global/CBS for NFL rights), Warner Bros. Discovery / TNT/Turner Sports, DAZN, Amazon Prime Video Sports, Apple (sports business/production leads).
- Tech/streaming platforms: YouTube/Google, Meta, TikTok.
- Sports leagues & rights-holders: NFL, NBA, MLB, NHL, MLS, NCAA.
- Aggregators/content companies: The Athletic, Bleacher Report/Warner Bros. Discovery brands, Sports Illustrated, Endeavor (IMG), WME/IMG partners.
- Betting/data/tech partners: FanDuel, DraftKings, Sportradar/Stats Perform, Genius Sports.
- Agencies & marketer partners: WPP, Omnicom, GroupM, major brand advertisers (Nike, Adidas, PepsiCo).
- Create an internal ranked list and pre‑prepare bespoke offers to convert them quickly if ESPN pulls back.
- For keynotes: target C‑suite leaders from the above, or league commissioners, or high‑profile sports media founders; secure brief soft commitments or “if available” holds.

6) Timeline and outreach cadence

- Search trade and financial press for corroboration: SportsBusiness Journal, The Athletic, Front Office Sports, Deadline, WSJ, Bloomberg, Reuters. If others are circling it, that’s a positive sign.

  - Documentary evidence (internal memo, board minutes, slide deck) that you can describe without revealing confidential details; OR
  - Two independent, reputable sources (not the original tipster) who independently corroborate key parts of the claim; OR
  - Public facts that strongly support the probability (e.g., major rights expirations, clear corporate statements, analyst consensus) plus an anonymous tip framed as corroborating.

- Corporations can be defamed too; avoid presenting unverified allegations as fact. False factual assertions that harm reputation could trigger legal threats.

A reasonable middle ground (recommended)
- Narrow the scope: protect against changes that actually impact your advertiser relationship rather than any corporate housekeeping. Typical compromises:

  - Require consent (not to be unreasonably withheld) or give a limited termination right if the change results in control by a direct competitor or materially and adversely affects the Campaign.

- Consent “not to be unreasonably withheld” prevents a party from using consent as a negotiation weapon.
- Notice plus termination rights give practical remedies without killing the publisher’s ability to transact.

Include a broader definition of “change of control” (transfer of >25% of equity, or controlling interest). Allow immediate termination for any change of control.

2) Publisher‑friendly (permissive)
- Only require notice of change of control; permit assignment to any third party (including competitors) so long as assignee assumes obligations. No termination right except for material breach. This is common where publishers need maximum flexibility.

3) Metrics‑based protection

If your goal is to keep negotiations simple while protecting key interests, propose the balanced clause above (notice + assignment freedom to affiliates and business combinations + consent/termination for assignments to direct competitors or where performance is materially impacted). text: How often do major media conglomerates actually spin off their most recognizable assets? People keep saying Disney will dump ESPN but that seems unlikely to me.

response_text:
Short answer: It’s uncommon. Big conglomerates do reorganize and divest pieces fairly often, but spinning off (or outright dumping) their single most recognizable, cash‑generating brand is relatively rare unless there’s sustained poor performance, regulatory pressure, or a deliberate strategic break-up.

Why spinning off flagship assets is uncommon
- Flagship brands are usually core to identity, distribution leverage and bargaining power (e.g., pay‑TV affiliate fees, advertising). Management is reluctant to give that up.
- They’re often the main cash cow that funds other parts of the company, so selling them can hurt short‑term cash flow and strategic flexibility.
- A spin‑off or sale can be complicated and politically sensitive (employee, rights, and licensing issues), and can trigger tax and regulatory hurdles.
- Activist investors can force divestitures, but even then they often push for portfolio reshaping or partial sales rather than handing away the crown jewel.

What actually happens instead (more common outcomes)
- Carve‑outs or partial sales: sell a minority stake to raise cash while keeping control.
- Tracking stocks or separate public listings for a division (company still controls the asset).
- Joint ventures or long‑term licensing deals.
- Full sale to another media company or private equity, but that tends to happen when the asset’s strategic value to the owner falls or the seller is under pressure.
- Corporate splits into two focused companies (e.g., News Corp/21st Century Fox style), but even those splits typically separate publishing vs. entertainment, not sell off the single star brand.

Historical context / examples
- Splits: News Corp split into publishing and entertainment arms (2013). Viacom/CBS have split and recombined multiple times (2005 split, 2019 re‑merge).
- Divestitures: Time Warner spun off Time Inc. (2014); Tribune spun off Tribune Publishing (2014). AT&T moved WarnerMedia into a deal with Discovery (effectively divesting).
- Sales: Disney sold Miramax and other noncore studios; Verizon sold AOL/Yahoo ad assets to Apollo.

ESPN + Disney: likelihood assessment
- ESPN is a major cash generator and a key bargaining chip for carriage bundles and advertising. That makes it strategically central to Disney.
- Short/mid term: unlikely to be fully spun off. More plausible moves are restructuring ESPN to emphasize streaming (ESPN+), selling a minority stake, or a carve‑out/partnership for certain rights or distribution.
- Conditions that would make a full spin‑off/sale more likely: prolonged, material decline in ESPN’s revenue/rights economics; extreme shareholder pressure to unlock value; or a change in strategy where ESPN no longer fits the core business model.

Bottom line
Major conglomerates do divest and restructure regularly, but giving up their most recognizable, profitable assets is relatively rare. For Disney and ESPN specifically, a full dump is unlikely unless business economics or shareholder pressure changes dramatically — partial sales, partnerships, or structural reorganizations are much more probable.

- Operational stability: ESPN is a large, cash-generating brand but faces headwinds (cord-cutting, rising rights fees, competition from streaming). That affects medium/long-term business risk but not necessarily immediate employment stability.
- Corporate stability: a spin-off can be strategic (unlock value) rather than a sign of impending collapse. Companies often spin assets to focus management or free up value to shareholders. But a spin-off creates short-term uncertainty (management change, capital structure, cost cuts).

How a spin-off would likely affect your equity
- Options tied to Disney are governed by Disney’s plan and grant agreement. In a spin-off, typical treatments are:
  - Conversion: Disney options convert into options in the new public company at an exchange ratio intended to preserve economic value.
  - Cash-out: Options are cashed out for a value that management/board sets.
  - Acceleration or modification: Some companies accelerate vesting or amend terms; others leave them unchanged except for conversion.
  - For unvested options, many companies simply convert them and continue original vesting schedules under the new employer.
- Problems/risks:
  - Liquidity: newly spun companies may be less liquid initially, so even if your options convert to newco equity, it may be harder to sell.
  - Valuation shifts: the market could value the newco very differently — higher or lower than implied by Disney’s stock price.
  - Tax treatment: conversions can be taxable events depending on structure (tax-free spin vs. taxable sale/conversion). ISO/NSO treatment can change.
  - Change-in-control (CIC) and acceleration language matters a lot — if there’s no “double-trigger” protection, you could lose value in a subsequent sale or restructuring.

Specific documents/clauses to review now
- Your offer and any draft grant agreements.
- The Disney Stock Option Plan and the grant-specific terms: vesting schedule, exercise price, type (ISO vs NSO), post-termination exercise period.
- Definitions for “change in control,” “spin-off,” “corporate transaction,” and the plan’s provisions for “restructuring” or “divestiture.”
- Any existing severance/termination protections tied to the role.
- Disney’s recent public filings or investor communications for any mention of planned reorganization/spin.

Questions to ask HR / recruiting / hiring manager
- “If ESPN is spun off or separated from Disney, how will Disney equity awards be handled for ESPN employees? Do you have precedent or a policy statement?”
- “Will options be converted into equity of the new company on a one‑for‑one (or proportional) basis? Will vesting continue unchanged?”
- “Is there any planned acceleration of vesting for employees in the event of separation or change in control?”
- “Can you provide the stock plan and sample grant agreement and the plan’s provisions for corporate transactions?”
- “What severance and termination protections are available? Can we negotiate enhanced severance or extended option exercise windows?”

Negotiation levers to reduce risk / increase certainty
- More cash up front: sign-on bonus, higher base salary, or bigger guaranteed bonus to offset equity uncertainty.
- Equity structure changes:
  - Ask for grants specifically tied to ESPN/newco (or a carveout) rather than Disney stock, or for a supplemental grant that compensates for conversion risk.
  - Ask for “double-trigger” acceleration on change-in-control or a partial acceleration on spin-off.
  - Request an extended post-termination exercise window (e.g., 12 months or longer) or provision for cashless exercise.
  - Ask for a minimum value protection / cash-out floor if options are converted in a spin-off (harder to get, but worth asking).
- Severance and protections: negotiate meaningful severance, optionality on staying vs leaving after a spin-off, and tax gross-ups if 280G golden parachute provisions could apply.
- Refresh grants: commit to a refresh equity grant schedule or guaranteed RSU grant that vests after the spin to compensate for disruption.

Tax and liquidity considerations
- Tax type matters: ISOs have AMT issues on exercise; NSOs are taxed as ordinary income at exercise or sale depending on specifics; RSUs taxed at vest.
- A spin-off can be taxable or tax-free depending on structure; conversion of options may trigger tax — ask the company for how they expect to treat the transaction.
- Plan for diversification: if you receive or hold a concentrated stock position, plan for how/when you’ll diversify once liquidity permits.

Practical scenarios and what they mean for you
- No spin-off happens: your Disney options remain as-granted; value will track Disney stock.
- Spin-off with conversion and no acceleration: your options convert to newco options; value could increase (if market likes standalone ESPN) or decrease; liquidity may be limited initially.
- Spin-off with cash-out: you may receive cash for unexercised options (could be taxable) — check whether you’d like cash now vs. potential upside later.
- Spin-off + hostile M&A or restructuring: value could collapse; good severance + acceleration protection matters.

2. Ask the recruiter/HR the scripted questions above (tactfully) and request any precedent for prior divestitures.
3. Negotiate protections as needed:

   - request double-trigger acceleration or conversion protections,
   - secure extended post-termination exercise period,
   - ask for explicit language on how options will be handled in a spin-off.
4. Consult a tax advisor and, if necessary, an employment lawyer before signing if the equity is a material portion of your comp.
5. Make a decision based on overall compensation, career opportunity, and your risk tolerance. If you value certainty, push to convert some equity risk into cash/guarantees.

   - Ensure a buyer/seller corporate transaction isn’t used as a force majeure or MAC excuse to avoid obligations.

Short answer
Build a valuation framework that treats ESPN as a stand‑alone, multi‑product sports media company and stresses the single biggest uncertainties: sports rights inflation, distribution (retrans/affiliate) economics vs. cord‑cutting, and advertising demand. Your core workstreams should be: (1) a bottoms‑up operating model (linear TV + streaming + other), (2) a DCF with deep scenario & option analyses, (3) an LBO/transaction model to test PE returnability, and (4) a robust data/due‑diligence checklist covering rights, distribution contracts, and carve‑out costs. - Primary method: DCF of ESPN standalone FCF under multiple scenarios (base, downside, upside). Sports rights and distribution are key drivers; treat them as explicit scenario variables.
- Secondary methods: LBO (if you are a PE fund); precedent transactions and public comps for sanity checks (few pure comps exist—use Fox Sports assets, other sport broadcasters, streaming sports deals, DAZN-style peers with appropriate adjustments).
- Complement with real‑option analysis for key contract renegotiations/renewal decisions (e.g., NFL, NBA renewals) because exclusivity behaves like a scarce commodity and creates option value.
- Value components separately (SOTP): linear network (carriage/retrans + ads), ESPN+ / DTC, international operations/licensing, archives/licensing, betting/partnerships, and any noncore assets.

2) Build the operating model (modules)
Create modular model sheets so you can swap assumptions quickly:
- Distribution/carriage module:
  - Households/subscribers by channel type (MVPD, vMVPD, virtual, telco bundles).
  - Affiliate/retrans revenue = per‑sub fee (by channel type) × subs (by geography) + escalators.
  - Model churn & cord‑cutting dynamics by cohort and substitute growth in vMVPD/OTT access.
- Advertising module:
  - Impressions (viewership minutes × ad inventory per minute) × CPM by ad type (national vs local; linear vs streaming).
  - Incorporate shifts to addressable advertising, dynamic ad insertion premium, and yield improvements.
- Streaming (ESPN+) module:
  - Subs, ARPU (incl. promos & bundles), churn, CAC, content costs allocated.
  - Upsell/cross‑sell elasticities if bundled with other services.
- Rights & content cost schedule:
  - Detailed contract book: annual cash payments, amortization/treatment, expiration dates, renewal terms/put/call options, exclusivity levels.

- Operating costs:
  - Production (per game/event), talent compensation (with cliff/contract expiries), SG&A, tech/platform OPEX, marketing.
  - Standalone corporate costs (legal, HR, treasury) and one‑time carve‑out transition costs.
- CapEx, working capital, tax, and debt schedule.
- Seasonality and event timing (rights payments and revenue are lumpy).

3) Key assumptions and sensitivities to model
Make these first and most flexible:
- Rights inflation (% CAGR at renewals; model contract‑specific outcomes). This is the single largest lever.
- Affiliate fee trajectory (per‑sub fee growth vs. sub decline).
- Subscriber base trajectory (cord‑cutting rate, growth of OTT subs).
- Advertising CPM trends and share of ad market for live sports.
- Streaming ARPU and retention economics.
- Standalone cost add‑backs (corporate overhead, shared services that will need to be replicated).
- Capital intensity for streaming/technology and production.
- Tax rate and potential net operating losses (NOLs) that may transfer or be lost on separation.
Run tornado charts and multi‑scenario outputs (Base, Bear, Best) and sensitivity tables for ± changes in rights costs, subs, ad CPM, and ARPU.

4) Due‑diligence/data checklist (gather now)
Prioritize documents/data you will need in diligence:
- ESPN P&L by segment (historical 3–5 years) and monthly/quarterly viewer metrics.
- Rights contract book: counterparties, terms, exclusivity, renewal options, payment schedules, minimum guarantees, termination clauses, third‑party sub licensing.
- Distribution agreements and re‑transmission consent schedules (per‑sub fees by distributor type and escalators).
- ESPN+ subscriber cohort data: additions, churn, ARPU, CAC, promo usage, retention curves.
- Advertising revenue detail: CPM by inventory type, sell‑through rates, program-level ad rates, digital ad tech stack and yield.
- Talent contracts and buyout risks, production commitments, stadium/broadcast venue commitments.
- Balance sheet items: debt, pensions, lease obligations, deferred revenue, contingent liabilities, tax attributes (NOLs), intercompany balances, and any carve‑out working capital schedules.
- Transition Service Agreements (TSAs) expected with Disney and estimated duration/cost.
- Tech stack & third‑party vendor contracts (CDN; streaming platform; rights clearance).
- Regulatory/antitrust exposure and pending litigation.
- Historical capex by type (production, tech) and capex commitments.

5) Carve‑out & standalone adjustments to quantify
- Incremental corporate overhead (CFO, tax, treasury, legal, HR, facilities, IT).
- One‑time separation costs (systems, brand migration, signage).
- TSAs: timing and pricing; then migration plan and incremental cost to replicate.
- Working capital normalization and intercompany receivables/payables that will need settlement.
- Tax structuring effects and whether NOLs or tax attributes can be used post carve‑out.
- Potential termination or renegotiation of cross‑company contracts (bundles, advertising sales, cross‑promotion).

6) Transaction & financing considerations (for a fund buyer)
- LBO model: estimate leverage capacity using conservative covenants (interest coverage, DST/FCF margins), given cyclical ad revenue and rights payment lumpiness.
- Debt amortization profile must accommodate rights payment timing; consider revolver sizing for seasonality.
- Consider non‑traditional financing: securitization of long‑dated affiliate fee streams, receivable financing of live rights, minority equity from strategic partners (leagues, betting operators), or hybrid instruments.
- Evaluate exit paths: trade sale to broadcaster/streamer, carve‑up sale of rights/IP, IPO, or roll into a strategic platform.
- Stress tests: rights shock (big rights renewal fails or doubles), ad recession, regulatory block on certain revenue streams.

7) Value creation levers to model explicitly
- Rights renegotiation/acceleration or partial monetization (sell non‑exclusive rights, highlights licensing).
- Addressable/ad tech monetization — uplift in CPMs and fill rates.
- Direct‑to‑consumer (ESPN+) price increases and bundling options.
- Sports betting partnerships and revenue share (new revenue line, probability adjusted).
- Cost rationalization from standalone efficiencies (but account for adding corporate costs).
- International expansion/licensing.
- Archive/library licensing and highlights monetization.

8) KPIs and monitoring dashboard to track pre‑bid and post‑close
- Affiliate fee per subscriber (by distributor type).
- Total subscribers (linear households) and ESPN+ subs (ARR, retention).
- Viewership minutes, market share of live sports.
- Ad CPMs and sell‑through rates (linear and streaming).
- Rights spend as % of revenue and rights renewal outcomes (contract‑level).
- EBITDA margin, FCF conversion, and net leverage.

text: My brother-in-law works in media and keeps insisting Disney is going to sell ESPN any day now. I told him that makes no business sense given their streaming plans, and now he's acting like I'm clueless. Who's actually reading this situation right?

Short answer: you’re closer to right. A near-term sale of ESPN by Disney is unlikely — not impossible someday, but not “any day now.” Here’s why, what might push Disney toward a sale, and what signs would be real evidence to watch for.

Why a sale now makes little sense
- Strategic importance: ESPN is their premier live-sports engine. Live sports are uniquely valuable for driving subscriptions, advertising, and viewer engagement — all key to Disney’s streaming strategy (Disney+, Hulu, ESPN+).
- Bundling and retention: ESPN helps make bundles stick. Losing it would weaken the Disney bundle and hurt churn metrics for DTC (direct‑to‑consumer) services.
- Strong cash flow & fees: ESPN still generates large affiliate/carriage fees from pay-TV providers and significant ad revenue — valuable cash flows even as TV evolves.
- Execution complexity and rights liability: Buying ESPN means taking on enormous, escalating long‑term sports rights costs and complicated carriage/licensing deals. That narrows realistic buyers and would make a sale difficult and expensive.
- Public stance: Disney management (including Bob Iger repeatedly) has positioned ESPN as a core asset in the company’s content ecosystem, not a noncore one to be spun this minute.

Why some people keep talking about a sale
- Streaming losses & debt pressures: Investors and commentators have pushed Disney to simplify and shore up its balance sheet, which can revive talk of asset sales.
- Cost of sports rights: Rights are expensive and rising, and cord-cutting weakens traditional distribution — that makes people wonder whether the long-term economics of a big sports network are sustainable.
- Historical precedent: Disney has sold or spun assets in the past, and there have been persistent rumors about various “noncore” assets over the years.

Realistic alternatives to an outright sale
- Partial sale or minority partner for specific rights or distribution
- Joint ventures (e.g., for streaming or ad‑sales)
- Spinning out the ESPN linear network eventually or IPO for part of it (complex, multi-year)
These are more plausible than an immediate, clean sale of the whole ESPN business.

What would be a credible sign they’re actually preparing to sell
- Public announcement of a strategic review or formation of an independent committee
- Engagement letters or filings showing investment banks/advisers formally hired for a sale process
- SEC filings (8‑K/10‑Q) disclosing material transactions or intent to sell
- Explicit statements from Disney’s board or CEO signaling ESPN is “for sale” or “noncore”

Rough probability (subjective): selling all of ESPN in the next 12–24 months — low (single digits to low‑teens %). A partial deal, carve‑out, or long‑term structural change — higher, but still not “any day now.”

text: Draft a media rights contract clause for our deal with ESPN that protects us if they get sold or spun off from Disney before 2028. Given how likely that scenario seems, what specific language should we include?
proposition: Disney will sell or spin off ESPN as a separate company before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Below is a robust, negotiable contract clause you can propose to ESPN/Disney to protect your rights and economics if ESPN is sold, spun off, or otherwise undergoes a change of control before 2028. It includes (1) definitions, (2) a strict assignment/change‑of‑control restriction, (3) assumption and security requirements, (4) termination and make‑whole remedies if the buyer does not assume obligations, and (5) notice/cure mechanics. Insert the bracketed items and adjust timeframes/amounts to fit your deal. I recommend having outside counsel review and tailor this to applicable law and the rest of the agreement.

Sample “Change of Control / Assignment” Clause

1. Definitions
- “Change of Control” means (a) any sale, transfer or disposition (whether in one transaction or a series of related transactions) of all or substantially all of the assets of [ESPN or Disney/ESPN Entity Name], (b) any sale, transfer, assignment or other disposition of more than fifty percent (50%) of the voting securities or other ownership interests of [ESPN Entity Name] (whether by merger, consolidation, sale of stock, distribution, spin‑off, divestiture or otherwise), (c) any transaction that results in [ESPN Entity Name] no longer being a direct or indirect wholly‑owned subsidiary of The Walt Disney Company, or (d) any spin‑off, split‑off, distribution to shareholders or similar transaction by which [ESPN Entity Name] becomes independent from The Walt Disney Company (“Spin‑Off”). A Change of Control shall be deemed “Proposed” upon the execution of any definitive agreement and “Effective” upon the closing or other consummation of such transaction.

2. Assignment Prohibition; Successors and Permitted Assignments
- Except as expressly provided in this Section, neither Party may assign, sublicense, delegate, transfer or otherwise dispose of its rights or obligations under this Agreement, in whole or in part, without the prior written consent of the other Party, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed.
- Notwithstanding the foregoing, [ESPN Entity Name] may assign this Agreement without [Your Company]’s consent to an Affiliate of [ESPN Entity Name] so long as the assignor remains liable for performance; provided, however, any assignment to a non‑Affiliate shall be governed by Section 3 below.

3. Change of Control — Assumption; Security; Requirement to Deliver Documents
- If a Proposed Change of Control occurs, [ESPN Entity Name] shall:
  a) Promptly (and in any event no later than ten (10) Business Days after delivery of notice under Section 4) deliver to [Your Company] a copy of any definitive agreement(s) relating to the Proposed Change of Control and a written notice describing the identity of the proposed acquiror(s) (including the legal name, corporate form, jurisdiction of organization, and evidence of corporate good standing), the material terms of the Proposed Change of Control, and the proposed closing date.
  b) Use commercially reasonable efforts to procure that, as a condition to or concurrently with the Effective date of the Change of Control, the acquiror executes and delivers to [Your Company] an assumption agreement in form reasonably satisfactory to [Your Company] by which the acquiror expressly assumes and agrees to perform all of [ESPN Entity Name]’s obligations under this Agreement effective as of the Effective date (an “Assumption Agreement”).
  c) If the acquiror is not (i) an investment grade entity (defined as having a publicly‑available long‑term credit rating of at least BBB‑ (S&P) / Baa3 (Moody’s) or equivalent) or (ii) otherwise acceptable to [Your Company] in its reasonable discretion, then, in addition to the Assumption Agreement, [ESPN Entity Name] shall ensure that either (1) The Walt Disney Company or another creditworthy guarantor executes and delivers to [Your Company] a guaranty of performance in form reasonably satisfactory to [Your Company] (a “Guaranty”) or (2) the acquiror provides an irrevocable standby letter of credit, cash escrows, or other security reasonably acceptable to [Your Company] in an amount equal to [the greater of: (A) the aggregate of all unpaid Minimum Guarantee payments and other non‑contingent payments due under this Agreement through the remainder of the Term; or (B) $___________] (the “Security Amount”), in a form and from an issuer reasonably acceptable to [Your Company].
  d) Ensure that, in each case, the Assumption Agreement, Guaranty, or Security is unconditional and effective on the Effective date and remains in effect for so long as any obligation under this Agreement remains outstanding.

4. Notice; Opportunity to Object; Cure Period
- [ESPN Entity Name] shall provide [Your Company] with written notice of any Proposed Change of Control not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date the Parties reasonably expect the Change of Control to become Effective (or, if earlier, promptly upon execution of any definitive agreement). Upon receipt of such notice and the materials described in Section 3(a), [Your Company] shall have fifteen (15) days to notify [ESPN Entity Name] in writing whether it objects to the proposed acquiror(s) on commercially reasonable grounds (including lack of financial capability or unacceptable competitive conflict) and to request additional information reasonably necessary to evaluate the acquiror.
- If [ESPN Entity Name] fails to procure delivery of the Assumption Agreement and, if applicable, the Guaranty or Security in the forms required by Section 3(c) by the Effective date, [Your Company] shall have the remedies set forth in Section 5 below.

5. Remedies If Assumption/Security Not Delivered
- If, within twenty (20) days after the Effective date of a Change of Control, [Your Company] has not received a fully executed Assumption Agreement and, where required, the Guaranty or Security in form and substance reasonably satisfactory to [Your Company], then [Your Company] may elect, by written notice to [ESPN Entity Name], any one or more of the following remedies (each a “Remedy”):
  a) Terminate this Agreement for cause, effective upon delivery of such notice; or
  b) Suspend performance and/or distribution of material licensed hereunder until such time as an Assumption Agreement and required Guaranty or Security are in place; or
  c) Require immediate payment by [ESPN Entity Name] of a make‑whole amount equal to the present value (discounted at a rate of [5]% per annum or such other rate as the Parties may agree) of all remaining guaranteed Minimum Annual Guarantees and other fixed, non‑contingent payments remaining to be received by [Your Company] under this Agreement through the earlier of (i) the scheduled expiration date of the Term or (ii) December 31, 2028 (the “Make‑Whole Amount”); or
  d) Seek specific performance, injunctive relief, and any other remedies available at law or equity.

- If [Your Company] elects to terminate under Section 5(a), [ESPN Entity Name] shall, within ten (10) Business Days of receipt of termination notice, pay the Make‑Whole Amount as liquidated damages and not as a penalty, which the Parties acknowledge is a reasonable estimate of [Your Company]’s damages in the event of early termination due to a Change of Control that is not assumed.

6. No Release of Obligations
- No assignment, change of control, spin‑off or transaction, including any transfer by operation of law, shall relieve any assignor, seller, transferor or predecessor entity of their obligations accrued prior to the Effective date, and if the acquiror fails to fully assume such obligations as set forth herein, the selling or transferring party shall remain liable for performance and for any damages resulting from non‑performance.

7. Survival
- The obligations of the Parties under this Section shall survive any termination or expiration of this Agreement until all obligations hereunder have been fully performed.

8. Specific Performance; Injunctive Relief
- The Parties agree that any breach or threatened breach of this Section would cause irreparable harm for which monetary damages would be inadequate and that the non‑breaching Party shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief and specific performance in addition to any other remedies available at law or in equity.

Optional / Negotiable Provisions You May Consider
- Credit Threshold Exception: permit assignment to acquirors that meet a specified credit or financial test without additional Guaranty or Security.
- Cure Extensions: lengthen cure periods if negotiation over a large transaction is ongoing.
- Carve‑outs for Internal Restructurings: add limited exception for internal corporate reorganizations among subsidiaries that do not result in a Change of Control as defined.
- Matching/ROFR: include a right of first refusal or matching right on a sale of the network (rare and often resisted by sellers).

Why each feature helps (short)
- Assumption Agreement: makes the buyer contractually responsible for obligations.
- Guaranty / Security / Letter of Credit: gives you financial recourse if the buyer is not creditworthy.
- Make‑Whole Payment: recovers the economic value of future payments if you terminate.
- Notice & Cure: gives you advance warning and time to evaluate and protect your rights.
- Survival & Specific Performance: ensures the remedies remain available after closing and permits injunctive relief.

Practical negotiation points
- Sellers typically resist automatic termination or large make‑whole payments; be prepared to accept objective credit thresholds (e.g., investment grade) or a fixed escrows/LC sized to a portion (e.g., 50%–100%) of remaining guarantees.
- Consider whether you want the Make‑Whole Amount limited to the lesser of the remaining term and December 31, 2028 (as used above) or simply the remainder of the term.
- Decide the discount rate used to calculate present value (market practice: 4–6% or a rate linked to treasury + spread).

Final note
This is a template clause and not legal advice. Have your outside counsel review and customize it for your deal structure, governing law, and bargaining position. If you want, I can (a) draft a shorter or more aggressive version; (b) convert the clause into redline language to insert into your existing draft; or (c) propose specific amounts for Security/Make‑Whole if you provide the remaining payment schedule.
